chapters.title: The Boast
chapters.shortDescription: The hare mocks the slow tortoise and challenges him to a race.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: Every morning in the forest, the proud [HARE] would [CHAT] loudly about every [RACE] he had won. His words rose like [HEAT] from the ground, and many animals pretended not to [HEAR] him. The tortoise moved slowly but with great [CARE], feeling each step on the [EARTH] beneath him, and never shed a [TEAR] when others joked about his short [EAR]. Deep inside, the tortoise knew that one honest [RACE] could change every [HEART] that watched.

chapters.title: The Race
chapters.shortDescription: The race begins; the hare speeds ahead and decides to rest.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: On the day of the race the path felt [SOFT] from the morning mist. At the signal, the hare dashed [FAST] from the line while the tortoise stepped [SLOW] but steady. Dust [FLOWS] behind the hare and [LOWS] of doubt ripple through the crowd, yet the tortoise keeps going. The hare is sure he will never finish [LAST], so he stops near some trees where [OWLS] sometimes rest and quickly becomes [LOST] in sleep. Meanwhile, the tortoise takes [LOTS] of small steps, each [FLOW] of effort carrying him closer to the finish.

chapters.title: The Lesson
chapters.shortDescription: The tortoise wins; the moral about steady effort is revealed.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: By the time the hare woke, the tortoise was walking with a calm and [STEADY] rhythm. Each step seemed to [STAY] on the path while his thoughts [STAYED] fixed on the finish line. The sun warmed the track and the air smelled like a simple [STEW], but no one looked away from the race. At the end of the [DAY], the tortoise crossed the line first, proving there are many [WAYS] to win if you choose the right [WAY] and keep moving. Animals from the [EAST] and the [WEST] all agreed and said, “[YES], slow effort with purpose is stronger than careless speed.

chapters.title: The Lion Sleeps
chapters.shortDescription: The lion meets the tiny mouse.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: Deep in the warm grass, the mighty [LION] was resting when a tiny [MOUSE] ran across his paw. With a sharp growl he lifted his heavy head, but the mouse showed no [SMILE], only fear. Instead of anger, the lion felt a soft [LINE] of mercy in his heart. The mouse promised to [USE] its small strength one day if needed. Amused, the lion let the creature go, believing such a small life could never matter.

chapters.title: The Lion is Trapped
chapters.shortDescription: The lion is caught in a hunter’s net.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: The next day, the lion walked proudly through the forest until he stepped into a hunter’s [TRAP]. A thick [ROPE] pulled him off his feet, leaving him hanging helplessly in a wide [NET]. He roared with all his strength, but no one was [NEAR] enough to hear. His mighty claws could not cut even a [NOTE] in the ropes, and for the first time he felt truly [LONE]. The forest grew silent as the great lion struggled with every [PART] of his strength.

chapters.title: The Mouse Saves the Lion
chapters.shortDescription: The mouse rescues the lion.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: Hearing the lion’s cries, the little mouse hurried through the trees to [SAVE] its old friend. Climbing quickly, it began to [RISE] along the tangled ropes. With sharp teeth it cut through each [ROPE] strand until the lion could [LIVE] freely again. The lion felt a deep well of gratitude and promised never to judge strength by size. From that day on, their unlikely friendship continued to [SOAR] across the forest, proving that every good deed finds its way back.

chapters.title: The Temptation
chapters.shortDescription: The fox spots grapes hanging high above him.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: The hungry [FOX] stopped beneath the vine and stared at the [GRAPES] above. He imagined one [GRAPE] after another—sweet as a [PEAR]—and forgot his [FEAR] of falling. He searched for a [ROPE], peered for a [PORE] or crack to climb, tried to [POSE] as if it were easy, then turned a dusty [PAGE] of plans in his mind, growing more [RAGE] with every try.

chapters.title: The Attempts
chapters.shortDescription: The fox runs and jumps again and again but cannot reach the grapes.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: He backed up, took a breath, and made a high [JUMP] to [REACH] the fruit. He tried with [CHARM] first, then with bold [CHAMP] confidence, but the vine stayed out of reach. Again he leapt, feeling a [CRAMP] in his legs, dreaming of a juicy [PEACH]-like bite. With each [CHAP] of dry throat and every heavy [HEAP] of effort, even a quick [HARE] would have paused—yet he kept trying.

chapters.title: Sour Words
chapters.shortDescription: Unable to reach the grapes, the fox pretends he never wanted them.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: At last he stepped back and said, “They’re [SOUR]!” to protect his [PRIDE]. He watched the leaves [RISE] and fall, and the grapes hung like a distant [ROSE] of purple. He wished he could [POUR] away his disappointment, but he spoke in a [RUDE] tone instead. With a final [SPUR] of stubbornness, he turned to [RIDE] his excuse, then tried to sound [PURE] and sure, though his heart was not so [SIRE].

chapters.title: The Trick
chapters.shortDescription: The boy watches sheep and plays a cruel trick on the villagers.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: A young [BOY] watched his [SHEEP] from a grassy [HILL] above the [VILLAGE]. Feeling bored, he began to [WATCH] the road below and suddenly [CRIED], “A [WOLF]!” The villagers rushed up the hill, only to hear his [LAUGH]. It was just a [TRICK], a loud [SHOUT] meant to amuse him.

chapters.title: The Lies
chapters.shortDescription: The boy repeats the lie, and the villagers grow angry and tired.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: The next day, the boy did it [AGAIN]. He [CRIED], “A [WOLF]!” and the [PEOPLE] once more [RAN] to help. When they saw the lie, their [ANGER] grew. They were [TIRED] of his [FALSE] cries, and their [TRUST] faded despite every [WARN].

chapters.title: The Truth
chapters.shortDescription: A real wolf appears, but no one believes the boy.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: At last, a real [WOLF] came to [ATTACK] the [SHEEP]. The boy stood [ALONE], shaking with [FEAR], and began to [CRY] for [HELP]. But no one came. Without [BELIEF], the flock was lost, a heavy [LOSS] caused by ignoring the [TRUTH].

chapters.title: Summer Days
chapters.shortDescription: The ant works while the grasshopper plays through summer.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: During the warm [SUMMER], a busy [ANT] gathered [FOOD] in the open [FIELD] each [DAY]. Nearby, the [GRASSHOPPER] chose to [SING] a cheerful [SONG] and [PLAY] instead of [WORK], laughing at the ant’s effort.

chapters.title: Preparation
chapters.shortDescription: The ant stores food and warns the grasshopper about winter.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: The wise [ANT] continued to [STORE] each [GRAIN] of food as [WINTER] grew closer. Through hard [LABOR], he learned to [SAVE] for the future. He used his [TIME] well and chose to [PLAN], even when others preferred [REST] and ignored his gentle [WARN].

chapters.title: Winter’s Lesson
chapters.shortDescription: The grasshopper suffers in winter and learns the value of work.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: When winter came, the [GRASSHOPPER] felt [COLD] and [HUNGRY]. He began to [BEG] the [ANT] for help and learned a hard [LESSON]. The ant chose to [SHARE] with [CARE], teaching that [WORK] today protects the [FUTURE].

chapters.title: The Crossing
chapters.shortDescription: The dog walks with meat and notices a shadow in the river.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: A hungry [DOG] carried a piece of [MEAT] while walking toward the [RIVER]. As he crossed a wooden [BRIDGE], he saw a dark [SHADOW] below. Holding the [BONE] tightly, he continued to [WALK], stopped to [SEE] his reflection, tried to [HOLD] his prize, and began to [CROSS] more slowly.

chapters.title: The Mistake
chapters.shortDescription: The dog snaps at the reflection and loses his meat.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: Filled with [GREED], the dog began to [THINK] he could have more. He stopped to [LOOK] into the water and saw an [IMAGE] staring back. Without pause, he tried to [SNAP], causing the meat to [DROP] into the [WATER]. In that moment, he would [LOSE] what he already had because of what he [WANT]ed.

chapters.title: The Lesson
chapters.shortDescription: The dog learns that the shadow was not real.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: The poor [DOG] watched the [MEAT] [FALL] away and saw the [SHADOW] vanish. What seemed [REAL] was only water light. His [PRIDE] faded as he failed to [GRAB] anything back. Left [EMPTY], he learned a hard [LESSON] about desire and loss.

chapters.title: The Discovery
chapters.shortDescription: The owner discovers that his goose lays golden eggs.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: A simple [GOOSE] on a quiet [FARM] surprised its [OWNER] each [DAY] by laying [EGGS] that were [GOLDEN]. The man would [FIND] them and grow [RICH], choosing to [KEEP] the bird [SAFE].

chapters.title: The Greedy Thought
chapters.shortDescription: The owner grows greedy and decides to take all the gold at once.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: Soon [GREED] filled his mind. He wanted [MORE] and thought if he could [CUT] open the goose’s [BELLY], he might get it [ALL]. Without time to [THINK], driven by [HOPE] for fast [GOLD], he began to [LOSE] everything.

chapters.title: The Loss
chapters.shortDescription: The owner learns too late that greed has destroyed his fortune.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: The poor [GOOSE] lay [DEAD], and the man found no [GOLD] inside—only [EMPTY] loss. Filled with [REGRET], he learned the hard [LESSON] that unchecked [GREED] destroys true [VALUE].

chapters.title: The Quarrel
chapters.shortDescription: The sons argue and refuse to work together.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: A wise [FATHER] watched his [SONS] argue each [DAY]. Their [ANGER] grew as they fought with [WORDS] instead of [WORK]. No matter how hard he tried to [TEACH], they would not [LISTEN], each holding onto [PRIDE] and causing [DIVIDE].

chapters.title: The Test
chapters.shortDescription: The father asks his sons to break a bundle of sticks.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: The [FATHER] gave the sons a [BUNDLE] of [STICKS] and asked them to [BREAK] it. They pulled with [POWER] and tried with all their [FORCE], but the bundle would not [BEND] or [SNAP], no matter the [TRY].

chapters.title: The Lesson
chapters.shortDescription: The father shows that unity brings strength.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: Then the [FATHER] separated the sticks, and each [SON] could [BREAK] one with [EASE]. He shared the [LESSON] that when people [STAND] in [UNITY], their true [STRENGTH] cannot be broken.

chapters.title: The Fight
chapters.shortDescription: A lion and a boar quarrel over water.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: On a hot [DAY], a [LION] and a [BOAR] met near a small [POOL]. Both felt [THIRST] and began to [FIGHT] with [ANGER], each wanting to [DRINK] first, driven by [PRIDE] and [RAGE].

chapters.title: The Danger
chapters.shortDescription: The rivals notice vultures watching them.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: As they fought, dark [BIRDS] circled above in the [SKY]. The lion and boar began to [SEE] the [DANGER] clearly and chose to [STOP] their fight to [THINK] and [WAIT].

chapters.title: The Lesson
chapters.shortDescription: They choose peace over conflict.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: Realizing the [TRUTH], the [LION] and [BOAR] stepped back from [WAR]. They chose [PEACE], shared the [WATER], and learned a [LESSON] about [UNITY] and [SURVIVE].

chapters.title: The Challenge
chapters.shortDescription: The wind and sun argue about strength.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: The [WIND] and the [SUN] argued about who was [STRONG]. They saw a [MAN] walking with a [COAT] and made a [PLAN] to test their [POWER] and prove their [FORCE].

chapters.title: The Wind Tries
chapters.shortDescription: The wind blows fiercely but fails.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: The [WIND] began to [BLOW] with all its [MIGHT]. The [MAN] held his [COAT] tight, feeling the [COLD], refusing to [REMOVE] it despite the [STORM].

chapters.title: The Sun Wins
chapters.shortDescription: The sun gently warms the man.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: Then the [SUN] began to [SHINE] with gentle [HEAT]. Soon the [MAN] felt [WARM] and chose to [REMOVE] his [COAT], proving [KINDNESS] stronger than [FORCE].

chapters.title: The Promise
chapters.shortDescription: A farmer hints at hidden treasure.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: A dying [FARMER] called his [SONS] and spoke of [TREASURE] buried in the [FIELD]. He urged them to [DIG] the [LAND] with [HOPE] and [CARE].

chapters.title: The Search
chapters.shortDescription: The sons dig but find no gold.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: The [SONS] worked [HARD], turning the [SOIL] and breaking each [STONE]. They [SEARCH]ed with [EFFORT] but found no [GOLD].

chapters.title: The Reward
chapters.shortDescription: The harvest becomes their reward.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: When [SEEDS] were planted, the [FIELD] grew rich with [CROPS]. The sons learned the [LESSON] that [WORK] brings true [WEALTH] and lasting [VALUE].

chapters.title: The Problem
chapters.shortDescription: A crow finds water too low to drink.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: A thirsty [CROW] found a [PITCHER] with [WATER] too low to [DRINK]. No matter how hard he tried to [REACH], the [LEVEL] stayed [LOW], leaving him weak and [TIRED].

chapters.title: The Idea
chapters.shortDescription: The crow drops stones into the pitcher.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: The [CROW] had an [IDEA]. He dropped small [STONES] into the [PITCHER]. With each [DROP], the [WATER] rose higher, slowly [FILL]ing the jar.

chapters.title: The Solution
chapters.shortDescription: The crow succeeds by being clever.
chapters.chapterTextTemplate: At last the [WATER] reached the [TOP]. The clever [CROW] could [DRINK] and felt [RELIEF]. His [SMART] [THOUGHT] brought a clear [LESSON].
